intro: Pastinaca sativa var. longa, commonly known as the scorzonera or wild parsnip, is a biennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and celery, and is characterized by its hollow, ridged stems and compound leaves. The plant produces yellow flowers in umbrella-like clusters, typical of the carrot family. Its roots are long and tapering, often yellow or white in color, and are used in traditional medicine and as a food source. The plant contains compounds like psoralens, which can cause phototoxic reactions when exposed to sunlight.
